meanings: To abandon means to leave something or someone behind and choose not to return, like when a pet is left alone or when you stop using a favorite toy forever.
examples: When the storm hit the beach, we had to abandon our picnic and run to find shelter from the heavy rain and strong winds.
The explorers decided to abandon their search for the lost city when they realized they had run out of food and supplies in the dense jungle.
In the middle of the movie, the main character had to abandon his quest to save the world when he discovered a secret that changed everything he believed.
During the science project, we had to abandon our original idea because it wasn't safe, so we quickly came up with a new plan that was much better.
After playing soccer for hours, I felt too tired to continue and decided to abandon the game, letting my friends play without me for the rest of the afternoon.

meanings: To abbreviate means to make a word or phrase shorter by using just a few letters or the first letters of each word, like turning "television" into "TV.
examples: In our science class, we learned that scientists often abbreviate long terms, like "microwave radiation," to make it easier to discuss complex topics quickly.
When I write notes for history class, I like to abbreviate important dates and events so I can fit more information on one page without losing any details.
During our group project, we decided to abbreviate some of the longer phrases in our presentation to make it clearer and easier for everyone to understand.
My teacher said we could abbreviate our names for the class roster, so instead of writing "William," I just wrote "Will" to save time.
In texting with my friends, we often abbreviate words like "see you later" to "CUL8R" because it's quicker and more fun to type!

meanings: Abroad means being in another country, especially one that is far away from where you live, like when you travel to places like Europe or Asia.
examples: My sister wants to study abroad next year so she can learn about different cultures and make new friends from all over the world.
In history class, we learned that many famous explorers traveled abroad to discover new lands and share their adventures with others.
When my family goes abroad for vacation, we always try to taste the local foods and visit places that are famous in that country.
The science project on endangered animals made me realize that some species are found only abroad, and we need to protect them to keep our planet healthy.
My pen pal lives abroad, and we exchange letters every month, sharing stories about our schools, hobbies, and the things we love to do.

meanings: Having a lot of something, more than enough for what you need. For example, if you have an abundant amount of toys, it means you have plenty to play with and share.
examples: During our science project, we discovered that the forest near our school is abundant with different types of plants and animals, making it a perfect place for our research.
My grandmother's garden is abundant with colorful flowers and fresh vegetables, so we decided to make a delicious salad for dinner together.
In the library, there was an abundant collection of books about space, which inspired me to learn more about the universe and our solar system.
After the rain, the puddles in the park were abundant, and my friends and I had a blast jumping in them and splashing water everywhere.
The soccer team practiced hard every week, and their abundant teamwork and determination helped them win the championship game at the end of the season.

meanings: To go somewhere with someone, like when a friend walks with you to school or when a family member joins you at a concert.
examples: I decided to accompany my little brother to the library because he needed help finding books for his school project on dinosaurs.
During the field trip to the science museum, our teacher asked us to accompany her as we explored the fascinating exhibits about space and the solar system.
When I went to the soccer game, my dad offered to accompany me so we could cheer for my favorite team together and celebrate their victories.
My friends and I love to accompany each other on our bikes when we explore the nearby trails, discovering new paths and enjoying nature's beauty along the way.
To make her birthday party more fun, my mom suggested that I accompany her to the store to help pick out decorations and snacks for all my friends.

meanings: To gather or collect things gradually over time, like saving up your allowance or collecting toys.
examples: As I read more books during the summer, I started to accumulate a list of my favorite stories that I wanted to share with my friends when school started again.
In science class, we learned how glaciers accumulate layers of ice over thousands of years, slowly shaping the land around them into beautiful landscapes.
My dad collects coins from different countries, and over the years, he has managed to accumulate a fascinating collection that tells the history of many cultures.
While practicing for the big soccer tournament, our team began to accumulate skills and teamwork, which helped us play better together and win the championship.
I like to save my allowance to accumulate enough money to buy the new video game that my friends have been talking about for weeks.

meanings: To adapt means to change how you do things so you can fit in or be successful in a new situation. For example, if you start a new sport, you might adapt by learning new skills and following different rules.
examples: When we learned about different climates in science class, our teacher explained how animals adapt to survive in extreme conditions, like polar bears growing thicker fur in the winter.
In order to enjoy our video game more, we decided to adapt the rules a bit so everyone could play together, making it more fun for all of us.
During the school project, we had to adapt our original idea after realizing some materials we needed were not available, but that helped us come up with an even better plan.
As the seasons change, trees adapt by shedding their leaves in the fall to conserve energy and then growing new ones in the spring when the weather gets warmer.
When my family moved to a new city, I had to adapt to a different school and make new friends, which was a little scary but also exciting.

meanings: An adversary is someone who is on the opposite side from you, like a competitor in a game or a rival in a sport. They are trying to win just like you are.
examples: In the championship basketball game, our team's biggest adversary was the rival school that always seemed to beat us in previous tournaments.
When the two countries had a disagreement, they became adversaries in a political debate that lasted for months, but they eventually found a way to work together.
In the exciting video game, players must defeat their adversary, a powerful villain, in order to save the kingdom from danger and restore peace.
During the science fair, my project faced tough competition, but my greatest adversary was the student who had won first place the year before with an amazing invention.
As I practiced for the school spelling bee, I knew that my main adversary would be my best friend, who was also a fantastic speller with a lot of determination.

meanings: Affection is a caring and warm feeling you have for someone special, like a family member or a close friend, that makes you want to hug them or do nice things for them.
examples: When my little sister hugs me tightly after a long day, I can feel the warmth of her affection, reminding me how much we care for each other.
In our science class, we learned that animals show affection in different ways, like how dogs wag their tails when they’re happy to see their owners.
During the holiday season, my family expresses our affection for one another by making special homemade gifts that show how much we appreciate each other.
As I read my favorite book about friendship, I realized that the main character’s affection for her friends helped them overcome challenges and support one another through tough times.
After winning the soccer game, my teammates celebrated together, and the affection we shared made the victory even more special and memorable for all of us.

meanings: To make a problem or a bad situation worse, like when you tease someone who is already sad, which can make them feel even more upset.
examples: When I forgot to study for the math test, my anxiety began to aggravate as I worried about whether I would pass or not.
The loud noise from the construction outside my window started to aggravate my little brother, making it hard for him to concentrate on his homework.
During the soccer game, my teammate's mistakes began to aggravate our coach, who was trying to help us improve our teamwork.
If you poke a bear with a stick, you might aggravate it and cause it to become angry, which is why it's important to respect wild animals in their habitats.
When I tried to help my sister with her puzzle, my constant questions seemed to aggravate her instead of making it easier for her to solve it.

meanings: High up in the air or above the ground, like a bird flying or a balloon floating.
examples: The colorful kite soared aloft in the bright blue sky, dancing playfully in the wind while my friends and I cheered from the ground.
During our science class, we learned about how hot air balloons float aloft, using heated air to rise high above the trees and buildings.
As the fireworks exploded aloft during the festival, the night sky lit up with brilliant colors, leaving everyone in awe of the spectacular display.
In the story, a brave knight rode his horse aloft on a steep mountain, determined to rescue the princess trapped in a tower far above the valley.
When we went hiking, we spotted a majestic eagle gliding aloft, effortlessly riding the warm currents of air high above the rocky cliffs.

meanings: To look closely at something to learn more about it or to figure out what it means.
examples: In science class, we learned how to analyze the results of our experiment to see if our hypothesis was correct or if we needed to change our approach.
When writing a book report, it’s important to analyze the main character’s actions and decisions to understand their motivations and how they change throughout the story.
During our history project, we had to analyze different sources of information to find out what really happened during the American Revolution and why it was important.
After playing the soccer game, our coach asked us to analyze our performance, so we could figure out what strategies worked and what we could improve for the next match.
In art class, we were encouraged to analyze famous paintings to discover the techniques the artists used and how those techniques made us feel when we looked at the artwork.

meanings: Anguish is a deep feeling of sadness or pain that makes you feel very upset or hurt, like when you lose something important or are really worried about something.
examples: When I saw my best friend upset after losing the soccer game, I felt a deep sense of anguish because I wanted to help her feel better.
The character in the book experienced anguish when he lost his favorite toy, and it made me think about how much I would miss my things too.
After studying for hours and still getting a low grade on the test, I felt a wave of anguish wash over me, making me doubt my abilities in math.
During the storm, the loud thunder caused my little brother to cry in anguish, and I had to comfort him to help him feel safe again.
Seeing the abandoned puppy in the rain filled me with anguish, and I knew I had to do something to help it find a loving home.

meanings: An antic is a funny or silly action that someone does to make others laugh or have fun, like a goofy dance or a playful prank.
examples: During the school talent show, my little brother performed an antic where he pretended to be a clumsy robot, and everyone in the audience couldn't stop laughing.
My friends and I planned an antic where we dressed up in silly costumes and surprised our teacher on her birthday, which made her smile from ear to ear.
At the science fair, one of the projects included an antic where a volcano erupted, spraying colorful liquid everywhere, and it became the highlight of the event.
While playing soccer, my teammate made an antic by pretending to trip over the ball, which tricked the other team into thinking he was hurt, allowing us to score a goal.
When we went camping, my dad's antic of pretending to be a bear while roasting marshmallows had us all giggling around the campfire as we shared spooky stories.

meanings: To anticipate means to think that something will happen in the future and to be ready for it. For example, if you know your birthday is coming soon, you might anticipate having a party and getting presents.
examples: I anticipate that our science project will win first place because we worked hard on it and included lots of exciting experiments to show the class.
As I opened my birthday presents, I could hardly contain my excitement because I anticipated receiving the new video game I had been talking about for months.
When the teacher announced a surprise quiz, I didn’t anticipate feeling nervous, but I quickly reviewed my notes to be prepared for any questions.
My friends and I anticipate going to the amusement park next weekend, and we can’t stop talking about which rides we want to try first.
After practicing for weeks, I anticipate that our soccer team will play well in the tournament and hopefully bring home a trophy!

meanings: Apparel is the term for the clothes people wear, like shirts, pants, and dresses. It includes everything we put on to keep warm, look nice, or express our style.
examples: At the school fashion show, students showcased their unique apparel, which included colorful outfits and creative accessories that highlighted their personal styles and favorite hobbies.
During our science class, we learned that certain types of apparel, like jackets and hats, can help keep us warm during cold weather by trapping heat close to our bodies.
When we went camping in the summer, we packed comfortable apparel like shorts and t-shirts so we could enjoy hiking and exploring the beautiful nature around us without feeling too hot.
My sister loves to design her own apparel, and she often spends hours sketching different outfits that she dreams of wearing one day for special events or parties.
At the local sports store, I found a cool jersey as part of my favorite team's apparel, and I couldn't wait to wear it to the game with my friends next weekend.

meanings: The quality of being interesting or attractive to someone, like a fun game or a cool toy that makes you want to play with it.
examples: The colorful artwork displayed in the school hallway has a special appeal that makes everyone stop and admire the creativity of our fellow students.
When we were deciding which movie to watch for our class party, the film's exciting trailer really helped it gain appeal among my friends.
The science project about outer space had a strong appeal because it included fascinating facts and cool images of planets that captured everyone's attention.
During the history lesson, the teacher shared a story about ancient Egypt that had such an appeal that all the students were eager to learn more about the pyramids.
My new video game has a lot of appeal because it features stunning graphics and challenging levels that keep me and my friends playing for hours.

meanings: To recognize how special or important something is and to feel thankful for it.
examples: I really appreciate how my teacher takes the time to explain difficult math problems, making them easier for everyone in class to understand and learn.
After finishing my science project, I appreciate the help my parents gave me, as they provided great ideas and support throughout the entire process.
During our art class, I appreciate the chance to express my creativity by painting and drawing, which helps me relax and enjoy my time with friends.
Whenever I read a good book, I appreciate the way it transports me to different worlds and lets me experience exciting adventures through the characters' eyes.
I appreciate how my soccer coach encourages us to work as a team and always reminds us that trying our best is more important than winning the game.

meanings: Feeling nervous or worried about something that might happen in the future, like taking a test or trying something new.
examples: As I walked into the classroom on the first day of school, I felt a bit apprehensive about meeting my new teacher and making new friends.
Before the big soccer game, I was apprehensive about whether I would play well and help my team win against our toughest rivals.
When I saw the science project due date approaching, I became apprehensive because I still had a lot of work to finish and wanted it to be perfect.
My sister looked apprehensive as she prepared to give her speech in front of the whole school, even though she had practiced many times at home.
As we hiked up the steep trail in the forest, I felt apprehensive about how challenging the climb would be, but I was excited to reach the beautiful viewpoint at the top.

meanings: Appropriate means something that is right or suitable for a certain situation, like wearing a swimsuit to the beach or dressing nicely for a party.
examples: It is important to wear appropriate clothing for the weather, so I always check the forecast before deciding what to put on for school.
During our science project presentation, we made sure to use appropriate language and visuals so that everyone could understand our ideas clearly.
When choosing a book to read for our class assignment, I looked for one that had an appropriate level of difficulty for my reading skills and interests.
In gym class, we learned that using appropriate techniques while playing sports can help prevent injuries and make the game more enjoyable for everyone involved.
My teacher reminded us that being respectful and kind to others is appropriate behavior, especially when working in groups or during class discussions.

meanings: Arid means a place that is very dry and doesn’t get much rain, making it hard for plants and animals to grow. It’s like a desert where there’s not enough water for things to live.
examples: The arid desert is home to unique plants and animals that have adapted to survive with very little water, making it a fascinating place to explore.
When studying climate zones in science class, we learned that arid regions can be found in places like deserts, where rain is scarce and temperatures can be extremely high.
During our vacation, we visited an arid area where we saw cacti growing and learned how they store water to survive in such dry conditions.
In history class, we discovered that ancient civilizations often struggled to thrive in arid regions, as they needed to find ways to access water for farming and daily life.
My friend and I enjoyed reading a book about a brave explorer who traveled through arid landscapes, facing challenges that tested his strength and determination.

meanings: Arrogant means thinking you are better or more important than others and acting like you don’t need anyone else. It’s like showing off and not listening to what other people have to say.
examples: Jason often brags about his soccer skills, which makes him seem arrogant, especially when he refuses to pass the ball to his teammates during games.
In the science fair, Emily was so confident that her project was the best that she came across as arrogant, making other students feel discouraged about their own hard work.
When Mia won the spelling bee, she celebrated her victory with such an arrogant attitude that her classmates felt upset instead of happy for her achievement.
During group projects, Alex tends to ignore others' ideas and insists that his way is the only right way, which can make him seem very arrogant to his friends.
After winning the championship, the team captain's arrogant remarks about how easy the game was made some of the other players feel like their efforts didn't matter at all.

meanings: To attain means to reach a goal or get something you worked hard for, like finishing a tough project or earning a trophy in a sport.
examples: After practicing every day for weeks, Maria was thrilled to finally attain her goal of winning first place in the school spelling bee.
In science class, we worked hard on our group project about the solar system, and I was proud when we were able to attain a high score from our teacher.
My soccer team trained diligently all season, and we were excited to attain the championship trophy after winning the final game.
By reading a new book every week, I hope to attain a better understanding of different cultures and ideas from around the world.
When I set my mind to learn how to play the guitar, I knew that with practice, I could attain the skill to perform my favorite songs.

meanings: Attire means the clothes you wear, especially for special occasions or events, like a party or a wedding.
examples: For the school science fair, I decided to wear formal attire, including a nice shirt and dress shoes, to show how serious I am about my project on space exploration.
During the winter concert, the choir students wore matching attire that included sparkly vests and black pants, making them look very professional as they sang for the audience.
When my family goes to fancy restaurants, we always put on our best attire, which sometimes includes suits and dresses, to make the evening feel extra special.
My friends and I dressed in superhero attire for the comic book convention, and we had a blast taking pictures and meeting other fans who loved the same characters as we did.
At the end-of-year party, everyone was excited to wear their favorite attire, from colorful dresses to cool sneakers, as we celebrated all the fun times we had during the school year.

meanings: Awe is a strong feeling of wonder and respect you get when you see something amazing or powerful, like a beautiful sunset or a huge waterfall.
examples: When I stood at the edge of the Grand Canyon, the vastness and beauty of the landscape filled me with awe, making me feel tiny in comparison to nature's wonders.
During our science class, we learned about black holes, and I stared in awe at the images of these mysterious cosmic phenomena that seemed to defy the laws of physics.
As we watched the fireworks light up the night sky, I felt a sense of awe wash over me, amazed by the colors and patterns that danced above us.
When my team won the championship game, the joy and excitement in the crowd left us all in awe, realizing how hard we had worked to achieve our victory together.
Reading about ancient civilizations in history class fills me with awe, as I imagine the incredible achievements of people who lived thousands of years ago.

meanings: To baffle someone means to confuse them so much that they can't figure things out, like when a tricky puzzle leaves you scratching your head.
examples: The math problem in our homework seemed simple at first, but it quickly began to baffle me when I couldn’t figure out how to solve it.
When I read the mystery book, the clues were so tricky that they continued to baffle me until the very last chapter.
During science class, the teacher's explanation of black holes was so complicated that it completely baffled everyone in the room, leaving us with more questions than answers.
My little brother loves to ask questions about space, but some of his ideas about aliens and planets really baffle me because they are so wild and imaginative.
At the game store, I was baffled by all the different video game choices, making it hard for me to decide which one I wanted to buy.

meanings: When someone is bankrupt, it means they do not have enough money to pay what they owe to others, like when a person can't pay back their allowance after spending it all.
examples: After spending all his allowance on video games, Jake realized he was virtually bankrupt and needed to save money for snacks at the school fair next week.
When the bakery down the street went bankrupt, it was sad for the whole neighborhood because we loved their delicious cookies and fresh bread.
During the history lesson, we learned that many businesses went bankrupt during the Great Depression, which made life very challenging for families across the country.
Samantha's lemonade stand was so popular that she was worried about going bankrupt after buying too many supplies before her big sale on Saturday.
When the family dog accidentally chewed up their favorite couch, they joked that they might go bankrupt trying to pay for a new one!

meanings: Beneficial means something that helps you or makes a situation better. For example, eating fruits and vegetables is beneficial for your health because it helps you grow strong and stay healthy.
examples: Eating fruits and vegetables every day can be very beneficial for our health, helping us to grow strong and stay energized for all our activities.
Studying regularly instead of cramming for tests is often beneficial because it helps us understand the material better and feel more confident during exams.
When we work together on group projects, sharing ideas and responsibilities can be beneficial, as it often leads to better results and makes the work more enjoyable.
Joining a sports team can be beneficial not only for improving our athletic skills but also for making new friends and learning how to work as part of a group.
Reading a variety of books is beneficial for expanding our imagination and vocabulary, making it easier for us to express our thoughts and ideas clearly.

meanings: Being benevolent means being kind and wanting to help others. It's like when you share your toys or help a friend who is sad, showing that you care about their happiness.
examples: The benevolent teacher organized a special field trip for our class, ensuring that everyone had the chance to learn about science in a fun and exciting way.
During the holiday season, our benevolent neighbor baked cookies and delivered them to every house on the street, bringing smiles to everyone’s faces.
In the story we read, the benevolent king helped the poor villagers by providing food and shelter, showing that kindness can make a big difference in people's lives.
My volunteer group worked hard to create benevolent care packages for families in need, and it felt great to know we were helping others in our community.
The benevolent character in the video game always offers help to players who are struggling, teaching us that it’s important to support each other in tough times.

meanings: A blunder is a big mistake that happens when you’re not paying enough attention, like forgetting to study for a test or mixing up your friend’s name. It can cause problems and make things more difficult.
examples: During the science fair, Jenna made a blunder by forgetting to label her experiment, which confused the judges when they tried to understand her project.
In soccer practice, Marcus made a blunder by kicking the ball in the wrong direction, leading to a goal for the other team and a lesson to focus more.
While writing his story for class, Liam made a blunder by mixing up the characters' names, which made his teacher laugh when she read it aloud to the class.
When baking cookies with my mom, I made a blunder by adding salt instead of sugar, and the cookies turned out tasting very strange and not sweet at all.
During the history quiz, Sarah's blunder was misreading the question, which caused her to answer incorrectly and lose points she had worked hard to earn.

meanings: To talk in a loud and boastful way, often to show off or scare others. It’s like when someone brags about how great they are or acts tough to make people pay attention.
examples: During the school debate, Thomas tried to bluster his way through the arguments, but his classmates saw right through his loud talk and focused on the facts instead.
When Jake started to bluster about how great he was at soccer, his friends reminded him that teamwork is what really makes a player shine on the field.
The teacher warned us not to bluster about our grades, because true success comes from hard work and dedication rather than just bragging.
As the storm approached, the winds began to bluster fiercely, rattling the windows and making us feel cozy inside with our books and hot chocolate.
In the video game, the villain would often bluster about his evil plans, but the hero knew that clever strategies would always defeat loud threats.

meanings: To refuse to buy or use a product or service because you disagree with something about it, often as a way to show that you want change.
examples: When our school learned that a company was polluting the nearby river, we decided to organize a boycott to stop buying their products and protect the environment.
After discovering that a popular video game was promoting bullying, many kids at school decided to boycott it and encourage others to play games that promote kindness instead.
During lunch, we talked about how we could boycott a restaurant that wasn't treating its workers fairly, and we planned to support places that treat everyone with respect.
In history class, we studied how people used a boycott during the Civil Rights Movement to protest unfair laws, and it showed us the power of standing up for what is right.
When our favorite toy company increased its prices too much, we thought it would be a good idea to boycott their toys until they lowered the prices again, so everyone could afford them.

meanings: A brawl is a loud and messy fight that usually involves a group of people getting into a physical argument or scuffle. It can happen in places like schools or sports events when emotions run high.
examples: During recess, a brawl broke out between two groups of students over a game of soccer, but the teachers quickly stepped in to restore peace on the playground.
In the history book we read, there was a famous brawl between two rival towns that started over a misunderstanding and ended up lasting for several days.
When my brother and his friends decided to have a pillow fight in the living room, it quickly turned into a chaotic brawl with feathers flying everywhere!
The video game tournament at school ended in a brawl as players argued over the rules, but the teacher helped them settle their differences and have fun again.
At the pet store, I watched a hilarious brawl between two puppies fighting over the same squeaky toy, and it made everyone in the store laugh.

meanings: To break a promise or rule that you agreed to follow, like not doing your homework when you said you would.
examples: When the team decided to change the rules of the game without telling everyone, it created a breach of trust among the players who expected fairness.
During the science project, we agreed to work together, but if someone doesn't do their part, it could lead to a breach of our agreement.
When I found out that someone was cheating on the test, I realized it was a serious breach of the school's honor code that we all promised to follow.
My parents said that leaving the door unlocked while we were away was a breach of our house rules, which are meant to keep us safe.
In the book, the main character faced a difficult choice when he had to decide whether to breach the secret agreement he made with his friend for a good reason.

meanings: Brief means something that doesn't take a long time, like a quick chat or a short story.
examples: The teacher gave us a brief overview of the science project requirements, making sure we understood what we needed to do before we started working in our groups.
During our school assembly, the principal made a brief announcement about the upcoming field trip, and everyone cheered with excitement when she mentioned the destination.
After a brief discussion about our favorite books, my friends and I decided to have a book club where we could share our thoughts and recommendations each week.
The weather report was brief but important, telling us that a storm was coming and we should prepare by bringing in anything left outside.
I watched a brief video on how to solve a tricky math problem, and it helped me understand the steps much better before I took my test.

meanings: Brisk means moving or acting quickly and with a lot of energy, like when you run fast during a game or walk quickly to stay warm on a chilly day.
examples: After a brisk walk around the lake, we felt full of energy and ready to tackle our homework together.
The coach encouraged us to run a brisk lap around the field to warm up before our soccer practice started.
As we explored the forest, a brisk breeze rustled the leaves, making our hike feel even more exciting and adventurous.
My dog loves to go for a brisk jog with me every morning, which helps both of us stay fit and happy.
During our science class, the teacher gave us a brisk overview of the solar system before we started our group project on planets.

meanings: A budget is a plan that helps you decide how to use your money wisely, so you know how much you can spend and save.
examples: This summer, I created a budget to save for a new video game, so I could plan how much of my allowance I needed to set aside each week.
When my family goes on vacation, we always make a budget to figure out how much money we can spend on fun activities, like going to amusement parks or trying new restaurants.
In our science class, we learned how to create a budget for a school project, which helped us understand how to manage resources and make sure we didn't run out of materials.
My friend and I decided to host a bake sale to raise money for our school, and we carefully planned a budget to cover the cost of ingredients and supplies.
To prepare for the upcoming school year, I made a budget for my school supplies, ensuring that I could buy everything I needed without overspending.

meanings: A buffet is a meal where you can pick and choose your food from different dishes set out on a table, so you can try many different things.
examples: At the birthday party, there was a delicious buffet filled with pizza, cupcakes, and fruit, allowing us to choose our favorite foods whenever we wanted.
During our school fundraiser, the cafeteria set up a buffet with different international foods, so we could taste dishes from around the world while learning about their cultures.
My family loves to host holiday gatherings, and we always prepare a big buffet with everyone's favorite dishes, making it easy for our guests to help themselves.
After the science fair, we celebrated our hard work with a buffet featuring sandwiches, snacks, and refreshing drinks, which made us feel like true champions.
When we went to the amusement park, we enjoyed a buffet lunch that included burgers, salads, and desserts, giving us plenty of energy for the thrilling rides ahead.

meanings: A campaign is a planned series of actions or events aimed at reaching a specific goal, like getting people to vote for a candidate or promoting a new product. It's like a team working together to win a game or get a message across.
examples: The students organized a campaign to raise money for new playground equipment, and they created colorful posters to encourage everyone to donate during the school fair.
During the election, the candidates ran a campaign that included speeches, debates, and fun events to convince people to vote for them.
Our science club is starting a campaign to promote recycling in our school, and we will hand out flyers and host workshops to teach everyone about its importance.
For our history project, we learned about how famous leaders used a campaign to rally support for their ideas, which helped change the world in many ways.
In art class, we decided to create a campaign using drawings and slogans to raise awareness about protecting endangered animals and their habitats.

meanings: To captivate someone means to grab their attention and keep them interested, like when a really good story or a magic trick makes you want to watch closely.
examples: The amazing documentary about ocean life captivated my entire class, making us eager to learn more about the creatures that live beneath the waves.
As I read the thrilling mystery book, the plot twists and clever clues captivated my imagination, and I couldn't put it down until I finished it.
During the science fair, my friend's robot project captivated everyone with its ability to navigate obstacles, impressing all the judges and visitors who came to see it.
When the teacher played the video about ancient Egypt, the fascinating stories and colorful images captivated us, making history feel like an exciting adventure instead of just facts to memorize.
At the zoo, watching the playful monkeys swing from branch to branch captivated the younger kids, and even I found myself laughing at their silly antics.

meanings: A captive is a person or animal that is being kept in one place and is not allowed to leave, often because they are being held by someone else.
examples: The documentary we watched in class showed how some animals are kept captive in zoos, which can be helpful for education but sometimes isn't the best for their well-being.
In the book I read, the hero had to rescue a captive princess who was locked away in a tower by an evil sorcerer, and their adventure was full of surprises.
During our science project, we learned about how certain species become endangered and may end up being kept captive in wildlife reserves to protect them from extinction.
At the animal shelter, I learned that many dogs and cats are held captive there until they find a loving home, where they can finally be free and happy.
When we visited the historical museum, we saw a display about how some people were held captive during important events, and it made me think about the importance of freedom.

meanings: Casual" means being relaxed and not dressed up or worried about things. For example, wearing comfortable clothes like a t-shirt and jeans when hanging out with friends is casual.
examples: On Fridays, our school allows us to dress casual, so I often wear my favorite jeans and a t-shirt instead of my usual uniform.
During our art class, we had a casual discussion about our favorite artists, and everyone shared their opinions in a friendly and relaxed way.
When we have a casual game night at home, my family loves to play board games and munch on popcorn while laughing together.
My friend invited me to a casual picnic at the park, where we sat on blankets, ate sandwiches, and played frisbee until the sun went down.
The science fair was a casual event, so instead of formal presentations, we could simply walk around and talk about our projects with our classmates.

meanings: A catastrophe is a huge disaster that causes a lot of harm or trouble, like a big earthquake or a terrible flood. It can change people's lives in a very bad way.
examples: When the science fair project fell apart just before the presentation, I felt like it was a complete catastrophe because all my hard work seemed to be wasted.
The unexpected snowstorm canceled our soccer game, and for the players, it felt like a catastrophe since we had been practicing for weeks to win the championship.
In the story, the hero faced a terrible catastrophe when the giant storm destroyed their village, forcing everyone to work together to rebuild and survive.
When my little brother accidentally spilled juice all over my homework, I thought it was a catastrophe, but I learned that sometimes mistakes can lead to new solutions.
The environmental catastrophe caused by pollution in the river reminded us all how important it is to take care of our planet and keep it clean for future generations.

meanings: A ceremony is a special event where people come together to celebrate something important, like a graduation or a wedding, often with certain traditions or rituals.
examples: The graduation ceremony at our school was filled with excitement as students received their diplomas and celebrated their achievements with family and friends.
During the science fair, we had a special ceremony where the judges announced the winners and handed out trophies for the best projects.
My sister and I watched a beautiful wedding ceremony on TV, where the couple exchanged vows and celebrated their love with a big party afterward.
At the end of the soccer season, our team held a ceremony to recognize all the players and coaches for their hard work and dedication throughout the year.
The local park organized a tree-planting ceremony to celebrate Earth Day, where community members gathered to plant new trees and learn about protecting the environment.

meanings: Clammy means feeling wet and sticky, like when your hands get sweaty or when the air feels damp on a rainy day. It can be uncomfortable and make you feel a little chilly.
examples: The air felt clammy and heavy as we walked through the foggy forest, making it hard to see the colorful leaves on the trees around us.
After running around during gym class, my hands felt clammy and sticky, so I couldn't wait to wash them before heading to lunch.
During the science experiment, the clammy slime we made with glue and water was so cool that everyone wanted to touch it and see how it stretched.
On a rainy day, the clammy feeling of the wet clothes stuck to my skin made me wish I had remembered to bring my umbrella to school.
When we visited the aquarium, the clammy air inside felt like a tropical rainforest, filled with the sounds of splashing water and colorful fish swimming by.

meanings: A clasp is a small device that helps hold things together, like a clip on a necklace or the buckle on a belt. It keeps items secure so they don't come apart easily.
examples: I struggled to fasten the clasp on my new backpack, but with a little practice, I finally got it to hold all my school supplies securely.
During art class, we learned how to make friendship bracelets, using a strong clasp to keep the beads from falling off when we wear them.
When I opened my favorite book, I found a shiny gold clasp that held the cover closed, making it feel even more special and exciting to read.
As we practiced for the school play, I noticed that the costume designer had used a clever clasp to attach the cape to the actor's outfit, making quick changes easier.
On our nature hike, I admired the way the butterfly's wings seemed to clasp together perfectly when it landed on a flower, showing off its bright colors.

meanings: To coincide means for two or more things to happen at the same time or to be in agreement with each other, like when two friends choose the same game to play together.
examples: The school play is set to coincide with the science fair, so I need to make sure I manage my time well to prepare for both events.
During our camping trip, the sunset and the sound of crickets seemed to coincide perfectly, creating a peaceful end to a fun day in nature.
When my soccer practice and my friend's art class coincide, we sometimes have to take turns spending time together after school, which can be a little tricky.
The date for our big field trip will coincide with Earth Day, so we are excited to learn more about the environment while having fun with our classmates.
As I read my favorite book, I noticed that the main character's adventure seemed to coincide with some of my own experiences, making it even more enjoyable for me.

meanings: To collide means to crash into something with a lot of force, like when two cars bump into each other or when a soccer ball hits a player hard.
examples: When two cars collide at a busy intersection, it can cause a lot of damage and make everyone involved feel scared and worried about what will happen next.
In science class, we learned that when two tectonic plates collide beneath the Earth’s surface, it can create earthquakes and even form mountains over millions of years.
During our soccer match, the players on both teams collided while trying to kick the ball, and we all gasped as they fell to the ground.
In the exciting book I read, the hero and the villain finally collide in an epic battle that determines the fate of the entire kingdom and keeps the readers on the edge of their seats.
While playing video games, my character can collide with obstacles, which makes it harder to reach the finish line, so I have to be careful and plan my moves wisely.

meanings: Colossal means something that is very, very big, like a giant dinosaur or a huge mountain. It's so large that it stands out and catches your attention!
examples: The colossal dinosaur skeleton in the museum amazed all the students on our field trip, making us realize just how gigantic these creatures were millions of years ago.
When we built a colossal sandcastle at the beach, it took all of us working together for hours, but the final result was so impressive that everyone stopped to take pictures.
During the science fair, my project about the colossal waves caused by tsunamis won first place, and I felt proud to share such important information with my classmates.
The colossal tree in our neighborhood park is so wide that it would take at least five kids holding hands to wrap around its trunk, making it the perfect spot for a picnic.
In the video game I love to play, there’s a colossal dragon that players must defeat, and it takes teamwork and strategy to conquer such a huge and powerful opponent.

meanings: To commence means to start or begin doing something, like when you commence a new school year or commence a fun project.
examples: The science teacher announced that we would commence our exciting new project on ecosystems next week, which made everyone eager to start researching their favorite plants and animals.
As the clock struck three, the students gathered in the auditorium to commence the annual talent show, showcasing their amazing skills in music, dance, and magic tricks.
Before we could commence our soccer practice, the coach reminded us to put on our shin guards and stretch properly to avoid any injuries during the game.
The librarian told us that we would commence the reading challenge next month, and I couldn't wait to dive into new books and see how many I could finish.
When the bell rang, it was time to commence our history lesson on ancient Egypt, and I was excited to learn about the pyramids and pharaohs we had read about.

meanings: To praise or speak highly of someone for doing a good job or having great qualities. It’s like telling someone "Well done!" for their hard work or achievements.
examples: I want to commend my teammate for scoring the winning goal during our soccer game; their hard work in practice really paid off when it mattered the most.
The teacher decided to commend the students for their amazing science projects, which showed how much effort and creativity they put into learning about the environment.
When I saw my little brother help our neighbor carry groceries, I couldn't help but commend him for being so kind and thoughtful to others in our community.
During the school assembly, the principal took a moment to commend the band for their fantastic performance, which inspired everyone in the audience to appreciate the power of music.
After reading a really inspiring book about friendship, I felt the urge to commend the author for capturing the true meaning of loyalty and support between friends.

meanings: To try hard to win or be better than others in a game or activity.
examples: During the science fair, my classmates and I had the chance to compete with our projects to see who could create the most innovative invention.
In our soccer league, teams from different schools compete every Saturday, and we always try our best to win the championship trophy at the end of the season.
When my friends and I play video games, we often compete to see who can get the highest score or complete the level the fastest.
During the spelling bee, I was excited to compete against my classmates, and I practiced every day to improve my chances of winning.
In a friendly competition, we decided to compete to see who could read the most books in a month, and it made us all enjoy reading even more.

meanings: To make something harder to understand or do by adding more parts or details.
examples: When we tried to build the model spaceship for our science project, adding too many details began to complicate the overall design, making it harder to put together.
During math class, the teacher explained that if we don't follow the steps carefully, it can complicate solving the problems and lead to wrong answers.
I wanted to make a cake for my mom's birthday, but adding too many flavors might complicate the recipe and make it taste strange instead of delicious.
While playing the new video game, I realized that choosing too many weapons and upgrades can complicate the gameplay and make it confusing to figure out what to do next.
When my friends and I planned a group project for school, we had to be careful not to include too many ideas, as that could complicate our presentation and make it hard to understand.

meanings: To compose means to create something, like a song or a story, by putting different parts together. It's like building with blocks, where each piece helps make the whole thing better!
examples: In music class, we learned how to compose our own songs by choosing different notes and rhythms to create something unique and fun to play.
For our science project, we decided to compose a poster that illustrated the water cycle, showing how evaporation, condensation, and precipitation work together in nature.
When we worked on our group presentation, each member contributed their ideas to compose a story about the importance of protecting endangered animals around the world.
During art class, I was excited to compose a colorful collage by arranging various materials, like magazine cutouts and fabric scraps, to express my creativity.
After reading the book, we were asked to compose a letter to the author, sharing our thoughts and asking questions about the characters and their adventures.

meanings: To agree to something or to say it’s okay for it to happen, like when you ask a friend if they can borrow your toy and they say yes.
examples: Before going on the school trip, we had to get our parents' consent to ensure they agreed with our plans and felt comfortable with us traveling.
In science class, we learned that scientists must get consent from volunteers before conducting experiments to make sure everyone is willing to participate safely.
When planning a sleepover, I always ask my parents for their consent first, so they know where I will be and who I will be with during the night.
My friends and I decided to start a club, but we needed consent from our teacher to use the classroom after school for our meetings and activities.
Before we could start playing the new video game, our older brother reminded us that we needed our parents' consent to make sure it was appropriate for us.

meanings: A consequence is what happens because of a choice you make or something you do, like if you don’t study for a test, you might get a low grade.
examples: When you forget to study for a test, the consequence is often getting a lower grade than you hoped for, which can be disappointing.
If you choose to ignore your homework and play video games instead, the consequence might be having to stay up late to finish it.
During a soccer game, if you don't pass the ball to your teammates, the consequence could be losing the chance to score a goal together.
When you leave food out too long, the consequence is that it can spoil, which means you won't be able to eat it later.
If you make a new friend by being kind and inclusive, the consequence is that you might find someone to share fun adventures with at school.

meanings: To conserve means to take care of something so it doesn’t get wasted or used up, like saving water or recycling paper.
examples: To help our planet, we should learn how to conserve water by turning off the faucet while brushing our teeth and taking shorter showers.
In science class, we discussed how animals like elephants and tigers are endangered, and it’s important to conserve their habitats to protect them from extinction.
Every time we recycle paper and plastic, we help conserve resources, which means there will be more materials available for future generations to use.
During our school project, we decided to create a poster that encourages our classmates to conserve energy by turning off the lights when they leave a room.
My dad taught me that if we want to enjoy nature for years to come, we must conserve the trees and plants by not littering and picking up trash when we go hiking.

meanings: Conspicuous means something that stands out and is easy to see or notice, like a bright red balloon in a room full of gray ones.
examples: The bright red apple on the green grass was so conspicuous that even the birds noticed it right away and flew down to take a closer look.
During our science project, we used a conspicuous chart with colorful pictures to help our classmates understand the life cycle of a butterfly.
When we went hiking in the forest, the enormous rock formation was conspicuous from far away, making it easy for us to find our way back to the trail.
In the school talent show, my friend's amazing dance routine was so conspicuous that everyone in the audience couldn't help but cheer and clap for her.
The teacher placed a conspicuous poster on the wall to remind us about the upcoming book fair, making sure that no one would forget to bring their money.

meanings: Constant means something that stays the same and doesn’t change, like the number of days in a week or your favorite color.
examples: In science class, we learned that the speed of light is a constant, meaning it travels at the same rate no matter where you are in the universe.
During our soccer practice, my coach reminded us that teamwork is a constant factor in winning games, helping us to work better together on the field.
When I study for tests, I find that having a quiet place to focus is a constant that really helps me concentrate and remember the information better.
In my favorite book series, the main character faces many challenges, but her bravery is a constant that inspires her friends to be courageous too.
The temperature in the freezer is supposed to stay at a constant level so that our ice cream doesn’t melt and stays delicious for a long time.

meanings: To construct means to build or make something by putting different parts together, like when you create a model with blocks or assemble a piece of furniture.
examples: In science class, we learned how to construct a model of the solar system using different-sized balls to represent each planet and their distances from the sun.
My brother and I decided to construct a treehouse in the backyard, and we spent the whole weekend gathering materials and planning how it would look when it was finished.
During art class, we got to construct our own sculptures using clay, which allowed us to express our creativity and imagination in a fun way.
As part of our history project, we had to construct a timeline of important events, carefully arranging them to show how they connected over the years.
For our school’s science fair, I wanted to construct a simple robot that could follow a line, so I gathered all the tools and parts I needed to get started.

meanings: To make something dirty or unsafe by adding something bad or harmful to it, like when food gets spoiled or water gets polluted.
examples: If we don’t properly dispose of our trash, it can contaminate the soil and water, making it unsafe for plants and animals in the environment.
During our science experiment, we learned that adding too much salt to the water can contaminate it, causing the fish to become sick and die.
When my brother spilled soda on the kitchen counter, I quickly wiped it up because I didn’t want the sticky mess to contaminate the food we were preparing.
It’s important to wash your hands before eating because germs can contaminate your food, making you sick if you accidentally ingest them.
The park ranger explained that littering can contaminate the beautiful lake, harming the fish and ruining the fun for everyone who wants to swim there.

meanings: Something that goes on and on without stopping, like a long song that doesn’t have any breaks.
examples: The river flowed in a continuous stream, providing water to plants and animals along its banks without ever slowing down or stopping.
During our science experiment, we observed the continuous reaction of vinegar and baking soda as they bubbled and fizzed for several minutes, creating a mini volcano effect.
In the library, I found a series of books that told a continuous story about a brave knight who faced many challenges on his quest to save the kingdom.
The soccer game was exciting, with the teams playing a continuous match for nearly two hours, each trying to score goals without any breaks in the action.
My mom's garden has continuous blooms of flowers throughout the spring and summer, making it a beautiful place to relax and enjoy nature’s colors.

meanings: To give your time, effort, or resources to help a group or project succeed. For example, you might contribute by helping a friend with their homework or donating toys to a charity.
examples: During the school fundraiser, I decided to contribute my allowance so we could buy new books for the library that everyone would enjoy reading.
Our science project was a big success because everyone in our group worked hard to contribute their unique ideas and skills to build an amazing volcano model.
At home, I like to contribute by helping my parents with chores, like washing the dishes or vacuuming, so we can keep our house clean and organized together.
My soccer team members all agreed to contribute extra practice time after school, knowing that it would help us improve our skills and perform better in the next game.
For our community clean-up day, I encouraged my friends to contribute by picking up litter in the park, which would make our neighborhood a nicer place for everyone to enjoy.

meanings: A controversy is a serious disagreement or debate about an important issue, often involving different opinions that people feel strongly about.
examples: The new school policy about cell phone usage during class caused a lot of controversy among students, teachers, and parents, with people having strong opinions on both sides of the issue.

In our history class, we learned about the controversy surrounding the signing of the Declaration of Independence, as some people supported it while others felt it was wrong to break away from Britain.
My brother and I had a big controversy over which video game to play, because he wanted to play a racing game while I preferred an adventure game that I had just bought.

The documentary we watched in science class sparked a controversy about climate change, with some classmates arguing that it's a serious issue while others were skeptical about its effects on our planet.
During the school election, there was a lot of controversy about the best candidate for student council president, as each candidate had different ideas about how to improve our school.

meanings: Convenient means something that is easy to use or get to, and it helps you do things without any trouble.
examples: It was really convenient when my teacher assigned the project on a topic I love, because I could use my favorite books and websites for research.
After school, I found it convenient to have a snack prepared in the fridge, so I could quickly grab it before starting my homework.
The new video game console is convenient because it allows my friends and me to play together online, even when we’re at our own houses.
Our school library has a convenient online catalog, making it easy for us to find books for our reports without having to search through the shelves.
I think it’s convenient that my parents let me use their tablet for my science project, as it has all the apps I need to create a cool presentation.

meanings: Cordial means being friendly and kind to others, like when you greet a new student with a smile and invite them to play.
examples: When we invited our new neighbor to the birthday party, she was very cordial and brought a delicious cake that everyone enjoyed.
The teacher encouraged us to be cordial to each other in class, reminding us that kindness helps everyone feel included and happy.
During the science fair, the students were cordial to the judges, greeting them with smiles and answering their questions enthusiastically about their projects.
After the soccer game, the players from both teams shook hands and exchanged cordial compliments, showing good sportsmanship despite the competition.
When I visited my grandma, she gave me a cordial welcome with warm hugs and freshly baked cookies, making me feel right at home.

meanings: To slowly break down or damage something, usually metal, because of a chemical reaction, like when rust forms on a bicycle left outside in the rain.
examples: If you leave a metal bike out in the rain for too long, the water can corrode the metal and make it rusty and weak.
In science class, we learned that saltwater can corrode metal faster than regular water, which is why boats need special paint to protect them.
When we visited an old castle, our guide explained how the walls began to corrode over time due to exposure to weather and pollution.
My dad showed me how vinegar can corrode certain metals, so we had to be careful while cleaning some of our kitchen utensils.
If we don't take care of our garden tools by cleaning and storing them properly, they might corrode and become unusable before the next planting season.

meanings: A council is a group of people who come together to discuss important topics and make decisions that help their community or organization. They work as a team to solve problems and give advice.
examples: The student council at our school meets every week to discuss new ideas for improving the playground and organizing fun events for everyone to enjoy.
During the town meeting, the council decided to plant more trees in the park to create a better environment for the community and wildlife.
Our science club formed a council to plan exciting experiments and share interesting findings with our classmates during the school science fair.
The local council held a special session to talk about ways to keep our rivers clean and protect the fish that live in them for future generations.
In the story we read, a brave council of animals came together to protect their forest from danger and ensure everyone lived happily ever after.

meanings: Custody is when someone is given the responsibility to take care of a child or an important thing, like a pet or property, usually decided by a court.
examples: After the parents decided to separate, they had to determine who would have custody of their children during the school week and the weekends.
In the story I read, the brave knight fought to win custody of the enchanted castle from the evil sorcerer who had stolen it.
When a pet is abandoned, animal shelters take custody of them until they can find a loving home for each furry friend.
During the science fair, my teacher explained how the school takes custody of the projects to ensure they are safe until the big day arrives.
After the accident, the judge decided that the grandparents would have custody of the children to provide them with a stable and loving environment.

meanings: Scattered pieces of trash or broken things left after something is damaged or destroyed, like after a storm or a building falling down.
examples: After the storm passed, we went outside to help clean up the yard, where we found lots of debris like fallen branches and scattered leaves.
In science class, we learned that after a volcanic eruption, the debris can cover nearby areas, making it hard for plants and animals to survive for a while.
When our school theater production was over, we had to clean up the stage, which was covered in debris from the colorful costumes and props we had used.
During our nature hike, we discovered interesting debris along the trail, such as broken sticks and animal fur, which showed us that wildlife had been nearby.
After building a fort in the backyard, we had to pick up the debris left behind, including bits of wood and stray nails, to keep the area safe for everyone.

meanings: To trick someone into believing something that isn't true, often by hiding the truth or lying.
examples: Sometimes, a magician can deceive the audience with clever tricks that make it seem like they are doing the impossible, even though it’s all an illusion.
In stories, characters might try to deceive others by pretending to be someone they’re not, which often leads to unexpected adventures or funny situations.
When my little brother told me he saw a dinosaur in our backyard, I realized he was trying to deceive me for a good laugh, and I couldn't help but giggle.
In history class, we learned how some famous leaders tried to deceive their enemies by spreading false information to gain an advantage during battles.
When playing video games, some players might deceive their opponents by pretending to be weak, only to surprise them with a sudden powerful move.

meanings: To declare means to say something loudly and clearly so everyone can hear and understand it, like when you announce the winner of a game.
examples: During the school assembly, the principal decided to declare that Friday would be a special day for everyone, allowing students to wear their favorite costumes.
After weeks of practice, our coach will declare the team lineup for the big soccer game, and I hope to see my name on the list!
When the science fair projects were presented, I was proud to declare that my experiment on plant growth won first place, thanks to my hard work and creativity.
As the final buzzer rang, the referee had to declare the winner of the basketball game, and all the fans cheered for our team’s amazing victory.
In history class, our teacher will declare the importance of the Declaration of Independence, explaining how it helped shape our country’s freedom and values.

meanings: Deft means being very good at moving your hands or body quickly and skillfully, like a dancer or a magician performing tricks.
examples: The deft way the artist painted the mural on the school wall amazed all the students, who couldn't believe how quickly he brought the colorful scene to life.
During our science fair, I was impressed by how deftly my partner handled the complicated experiment, making it look easy while explaining the process to the judges.
When we played basketball at recess, my friend showed off his deft dribbling skills, weaving between players and making it look effortless as he scored a basket.
The chef prepared a delicious meal for our family dinner, deftly chopping vegetables and stirring sauces, while sharing tips about cooking that made everyone excited to help.
As we watched the magician perform at the school assembly, his deft movements with the cards and coins left us all wondering how he could make them disappear so quickly.

meanings: To make something worse or of lower quality, like when a toy gets broken and doesn't work as well anymore.
examples: If we don't take care of our environment, pollution can degrade the quality of air we breathe and the water we drink, making it unhealthy for everyone.
When a student doesn't study for a test, it can degrade their chances of getting a good grade, which might make them feel disappointed later on.
Using too many chemicals in farming can degrade the soil, making it less fertile and harder for plants to grow, which is bad for our food supply.
If you leave a bike out in the rain without covering it, the rust can degrade its parts, and soon it won't work as well as it used to.
In a video game, if a character gets hit too many times without healing, their abilities can degrade, making it harder to win against tougher opponents.

meanings: To use up all of something so that there is none left, like when you drink all the juice in a bottle.
examples: If we keep using water from the lake without replenishing it, we might deplete the supply and hurt the fish and plants that live there.
During the science project, we learned that overfishing can deplete the ocean's fish populations, making it hard for them to recover and survive.
As I played video games all weekend, I didn’t realize I would deplete my phone’s battery and have to wait hours for it to charge again.
The school library has many books, but if students don’t return them on time, we might deplete the collection and not have enough for everyone to read.
When we went camping, we had to be careful not to deplete our food supplies too quickly, or we wouldn’t have enough meals for the entire trip.

meanings: To hold someone back so they cannot leave, often by the police or other authorities. It means keeping someone in one place for a while because they need to answer questions or follow rules.
examples: The principal had to detain a few students after school because they were caught playing pranks in the hallways instead of following the rules.
During the science project presentation, the teacher decided to detain the group for a few extra minutes to discuss how they could improve their teamwork skills.
When the soccer game was interrupted by a sudden rainstorm, the referee had to detain the players on the field until it was safe to continue playing.
In the library, the librarian might detain a book for a little longer if a student needs extra time to finish their research for an important school project.
While waiting for the bus, my friends and I decided to detain our laughter as we shared funny stories so we wouldn't disturb the other kids around us.

meanings: To find out if something is there or to notice something that is not easy to see. For example, a detective might detect clues that help solve a mystery.
examples: The scientist used special instruments to detect tiny changes in the environment, which helped us understand how pollution affects animals and plants in our neighborhood.
During our science project, we learned how to detect the presence of sugar in different drinks using a simple chemical reaction that changed color when sugar was present.
While exploring the forest, we tried to detect different bird calls, and with practice, we could identify which birds were singing based on their unique sounds.
In our history class, we studied how archaeologists detect ancient artifacts buried underground, using tools and techniques that reveal secrets from long ago.
When playing video games, I noticed a hidden clue that helped me detect the location of a treasure, making my character stronger and allowing me to win the level.

meanings: Working hard and being careful when doing tasks, like homework or chores, to make sure they are done well.
examples: Lily was diligent in her science project, spending hours researching the topic and creating a colorful poster that impressed her teacher and classmates during the presentation.
During soccer practice, the diligent players worked hard on their drills, which helped them improve their skills and win the championship game at the end of the season.
Mark showed diligent effort in his homework by completing each assignment carefully and asking questions whenever he didn’t understand something, which helped him achieve great grades.
As a diligent reader, Sarah set a goal to finish one chapter of her book each night, and her dedication allowed her to finish the entire series in just a few weeks.
The diligent team of students organized a fundraiser for their school, putting in a lot of time and effort to plan the event and raise money for new playground equipment.

meanings: To make something smaller or weaker; for example, when you eat a piece of cake, the cake diminishes as you take bites.
examples: As the sun began to set, the bright colors in the sky started to diminish, leaving a soft, peaceful twilight that made us feel calm and relaxed.
When I studied hard for my math test, I noticed my worries began to diminish, and I felt more confident about my answers.
After playing outside all day, the energy of my friends started to diminish, and we all agreed to sit down and enjoy some snacks together.
The amount of plastic in the ocean can diminish if we all work together to recycle and reduce our waste, helping to protect sea animals and their habitats.
As the days passed, the excitement for our school project began to diminish, but we still wanted to make it the best presentation ever!

meanings: Being discreet means being careful about what you say or do, especially when it involves keeping secrets or not embarrassing someone. It's like knowing when to keep quiet to avoid trouble or hurt feelings.
examples: When planning a surprise birthday party for my best friend, we had to be discreet about the details so she wouldn't find out what we were up to.
During the school project, I made sure to be discreet when discussing my ideas with my partner, as we wanted to keep our creative plans a secret until the presentation.
In a game of hide and seek, I chose a discreet hiding spot behind the big tree, making it harder for my friends to find me.
While working on my science fair project, I learned that being discreet about sharing my unique experiment idea helped me keep it special for the judges.
At the library, I whispered to my friend about the interesting book I found, as we wanted to be discreet and not disturb the other readers.

meanings: A disk is a flat, round object that can store information, like music or games, on computers and other devices. You can think of it like a shiny pizza that holds your favorite digital things!
examples: The computer's hard disk stores all of our important files, like pictures and school projects, so we can access them whenever we need to complete our homework.
During science class, we learned that a spinning disk can create energy, and we even built a small model to see how it works in real life.
My dad showed me how to use a blank disk to burn music onto it, so I could create my own special playlist for our family road trip.
At the library, I found a fascinating book about the history of vinyl records, which are large disks that hold music and have become popular collectibles for many people.
When we played frisbee at the park, I realized that the flying disk was a great way to practice my throwing skills and have fun with my friends at the same time.

meanings: Dissent means to disagree with or have a different opinion from what most people think. For example, if everyone at school likes a certain movie but you don't, that's dissent.
examples: During the class discussion about the book we read, some students expressed their dissent about the ending, saying they wished the characters had made different choices.
In our science project group, I showed my dissent when my teammates suggested we use only one type of material, as I believed mixing different materials could lead to better results.
When the soccer coach decided to change the practice schedule, a few players showed their dissent by sharing their concerns about how it would affect their other activities.
Although many people agreed with the popular opinion about the movie, my friend and I voiced our dissent because we felt the story was confusing and the characters weren't relatable.
In history class, we learned that dissent can be important in a democracy, as it allows different voices to be heard and can lead to positive change in society.

meanings: To dissolve means to mix a solid, like sugar or salt, into a liquid so that the solid disappears and becomes part of the liquid.
examples: When you add sugar to your iced tea, it will dissolve quickly if you stir it well, making the drink taste sweeter and more delicious.
In science class, we learned that when salt is added to water, it will dissolve, disappearing completely and creating a salty solution that we can taste.
While baking cookies, it’s important to dissolve the baking soda in warm water first, so it spreads evenly throughout the dough and helps the cookies rise perfectly.
During our art project, we used watercolors, and I watched as the colors would dissolve on the paper, creating beautiful swirls and patterns that amazed everyone.
When ice melts in a warm drink, it doesn’t just disappear; the ice actually dissolves into the liquid, making the drink colder and more refreshing for everyone.

meanings: Distinct means being clearly different from something else, like how a red apple is distinct from a green apple.
examples: Each species of bird in the rainforest has a distinct song that helps them communicate with one another and attract mates during the breeding season.
When we took a field trip to the museum, I noticed that each painting had distinct colors and styles, making them unique pieces of art that told their own stories.
In science class, we learned about how different animals have distinct adaptations that help them survive in their specific habitats, like the thick fur of a polar bear in the Arctic.
My two best friends have distinct personalities; one is very outgoing and loves to talk, while the other is quiet and enjoys reading books in her spare time.
During the school talent show, I was amazed by the distinct talents of my classmates, from singing and dancing to magic tricks and comedy that made everyone laugh.

meanings: To domesticate means to train wild animals so they can live with people and help us, like dogs or cats that become our pets.
examples: In science class, we learned that ancient humans worked hard to domesticate wolves, which eventually became the friendly dogs we have today.
When I visited a farm, I saw how farmers domesticate animals like cows and chickens to help provide food for our communities.
It’s amazing to think about how people were able to domesticate plants, like wheat and corn, allowing us to grow our own food instead of just gathering it.
In a video game, players can domesticate wild creatures, training them to help in battles and make their team stronger as they progress through the levels.
My little brother wants to domesticate a rabbit one day, so he often reads books about how to take care of pets and train them to be friendly.

meanings: Drastic means something that is very strong or extreme, like a big change or action that can really affect things.
examples: When the school announced a drastic change to the lunch menu, many students were excited to try new foods while others were worried about not liking them.
The scientist explained that the drastic increase in temperatures could lead to serious changes in our environment, affecting plants, animals, and even our own way of life.
After the team lost their first three games, the coach decided to make drastic changes to their practice routine to help the players improve their skills and teamwork.
When my mom saw the drastic mess I made in my room, she reminded me that keeping things organized helps us find what we need more easily.
