As we hiked up the mountain, the splendor of the view at the summit took our breath away, reminding us of how beautiful nature can be.
For her birthday party, my sister decorated the house with balloons and streamers, creating a splendor that made everyone feel festive and ready to celebrate.

meanings: Squalor is a situation where a place is very dirty and messy, often because people do not have enough money to keep it clean. It can make the environment uncomfortable and unhealthy to live in.
examples: When the community center organized a clean-up day, we learned that many people live in squalor, which inspired us to help make our neighborhood a better place.
In the story we read in class, the main character escaped from a life of squalor and found a way to create a happy home for herself and her family.
The documentary we watched about different countries showed how some children have to live in squalor, making us appreciate our own homes and the importance of helping others.
During our science project, we researched how pollution can lead to squalor in cities, highlighting the need for better waste management and cleaner environments for everyone.
After volunteering at the shelter, I realized how important it is to help those living in squalor, and we decided to organize a fundraiser to support their needs.

meanings: A stampede is when a group of people or animals suddenly runs away quickly, usually because they are scared or startled. It can happen at a concert, in a crowd, or when animals feel threatened.
examples: When the bell rang at the end of the school day, the students rushed out of the classroom in a stampede to reach the playground first.
During the field trip to the zoo, we watched in amazement as the elephants created a stampede when they got excited and started running around their enclosure.
When the ice cream truck arrived at the park, kids rushed towards it in a stampede, eager to get their favorite flavors before they ran out.
In the movie we watched, the wild horses galloped across the plains in a stampede, and it was both thrilling and a little scary to see them move so quickly.
At the science fair, when the judges announced the winners, there was a stampede of students rushing to the front to see if they had won a prize.

meanings: Not moving or changing; staying in one place, like a car that is parked or a person standing still.
examples: The bicycle was left stationary in the driveway while we ran inside to grab our helmets before going for a ride around the neighborhood.
During our science experiment, the stationary plant served as a perfect example for understanding how sunlight affects growth compared to the plants we moved around.
While playing soccer at recess, I noticed that the goalposts remained stationary, making it easier for us to score points and have fun with our friends.
The model rocket sat stationary on the launch pad, waiting for the countdown to begin before it would soar high into the sky, thrilling everyone watching.
In history class, we learned about how ancient buildings were designed to be stationary, allowing them to stand for centuries while surrounding landscapes changed.

meanings: A stench is a very strong and bad smell that can make you feel uncomfortable or want to cover your nose, like the smell of garbage or rotten food.
examples: After the rain, the stench of rotten leaves filled the air, reminding us that nature has its own unique smells, some pleasant and others not so much.
During science class, we learned about how bacteria can create a stench when they break down food, which made us all think twice about leaving our lunches out.
When my little brother forgot to take out the trash, the stench from the kitchen became so strong that we had to open windows to let in fresh air.
As we walked through the old, abandoned house for our history project, the stench of mold and decay made us shiver and realize how important it is to take care of our buildings.
At the park, we noticed a terrible stench coming from the nearby pond, which led us to discuss how pollution can harm the environment and the animals living there.

meanings: Stern means being very serious and not showing a lot of kindness or fun, like when a teacher has a strict look on their face when they want the class to pay attention.
examples: The teacher's stern expression made it clear that she would not tolerate any talking during the important test we were about to take.
When my dad gave me a stern look after I forgot to do my chores, I knew I needed to step up and help out more.
During the basketball game, the coach's stern voice motivated us to play our best and follow the rules without any excuses.
As we watched the documentary about sharks, the narrator's stern tone reminded us of the importance of protecting these amazing creatures from extinction.
My mom's stern warning about the dangers of running near the street made me realize how important it is to stay safe while playing outside.

meanings: To stop something from happening or to hold it back, like when you try to keep a sneeze from coming out.
examples: When the teacher asked us to share our ideas, I felt nervous that my fear would stifle my creativity and stop me from speaking up.
The loud music from the party next door seemed to stifle my ability to concentrate on my homework, making it hard to focus on my math problems.
If we don't take care of the environment, pollution can stifle the growth of plants and animals, affecting the entire ecosystem in our neighborhood.
During the science fair, I realized that too much pressure to win could stifle my enthusiasm for learning and exploring new ideas about the projects.
Sometimes, if friends make fun of someone’s dreams, it can stifle that person’s confidence and make them afraid to try new things.

meanings: To strew means to spread things out in different places, like when you toss leaves on the ground or scatter toys across the floor.
examples: After the school art project, we had to clean up the room where we had been painting, as colorful splatters of paint were strewn all over the tables and floor.
During our nature walk, we noticed how the wind would strew leaves and twigs across the path, making it look like a beautiful carpet of autumn colors.
For my birthday party, I decided to strew balloons all over the backyard to create a fun and festive atmosphere for my friends to enjoy.
When we baked cookies for the bake sale, flour got strewn everywhere in the kitchen, and we had to laugh at the mess we made while trying to have fun.
As we studied the history of ancient civilizations, our teacher showed us artifacts that were often strewn across the ground, waiting to be discovered by archaeologists.

meanings: To use one thing or person in place of another when the first one isn't available or can't be used. For example, you might substitute apples for oranges in a recipe.
examples: When our basketball team didn't have enough players, we had to find a substitute who could help us compete in the big game this weekend.
In science class, when we ran out of vinegar, our teacher suggested we could use lemon juice as a substitute for our volcano experiment.
My mom was out of eggs when she wanted to bake cookies, so she decided to use applesauce as a substitute for a healthier version of the recipe.
During the soccer match, our coach had to substitute one of the players to give him a break and to make sure everyone stayed energized for the second half.
When I finished my book series, I asked my friend for a substitute recommendation so I could find something new and exciting to read next.

meanings: Superb means something that is really, really great or better than everything else. For example, if you have a superb dessert, it tastes amazing and makes you very happy!
examples: The science fair project my group created was superb, showcasing not only our hard work but also our ability to explain complex ideas in a fun and engaging way.
After reading the superb book about ancient Egypt, I couldn't stop thinking about the fascinating pyramids and the mysteries of the pharaohs.
During the soccer game, my teammate made a superb goal that helped us win, and everyone cheered as he celebrated with a big smile on his face.
My mom's superb chocolate chip cookies are always the highlight of our family gatherings, and everyone asks for her secret recipe every time we have a party.
In art class, I painted a superb landscape that captured the beauty of the sunset, and my teacher praised me for using such vibrant colors and creative techniques.

meanings: Something extra that you add to make something better or to help it work well, like taking vitamins to improve your health.
examples: To improve our science project, we decided to use colorful charts and diagrams as a supplement to our written report, making it easier for everyone to understand our ideas.
During our history class, we watched a documentary as a supplement to the textbook, which helped us learn more about ancient civilizations in a fun and engaging way.
My mom likes to add a vitamin supplement to her morning smoothie, believing it helps her stay healthy and gives her extra energy to take care of our family.
In art class, we used glitter as a supplement to our paintings, making them sparkle and stand out even more during the school exhibition.
Our soccer coach told us that practicing our skills at home would be a great supplement to our regular team practices, helping us improve faster on the field.

meanings: The word "supreme" means the best or most important, like when you call a leader who has the most power or when something is at the top of its category, like the supreme champion in a sports competition.
examples: The supreme leader of our school’s student council organized a fantastic fundraiser that helped raise money for local charities and brought everyone together for a great cause.
In the world of sports, many fans believe that the supreme athlete is one who not only excels in their sport but also inspires others with their dedication and teamwork.
During our science fair, my project on renewable energy won the supreme award, which made me feel proud because it showed how important it is to protect our planet.
When we read the book about ancient civilizations, I learned that the supreme rulers had great power and made important decisions that affected the lives of everyone in their kingdoms.
In a game of chess, the supreme strategy often involves thinking several moves ahead, which can help you outsmart your opponent and claim victory in the match.

meanings: To keep something going for a long time, like taking care of a plant so it can grow healthy.
examples: To help the environment, we need to find ways to sustain our natural resources, like water and trees, so future generations can enjoy a clean and healthy planet.
In science class, we learned how bees sustain the ecosystem by pollinating plants, which helps produce the fruits and vegetables we eat every day.
Our team worked hard during practice to sustain our energy levels, so we could play our best in the big soccer game this weekend.
The librarian explained how reading regularly can help sustain our imagination, allowing us to explore new worlds and ideas through the stories we discover.
To sustain a balanced diet, it’s important to eat a variety of foods that provide the vitamins and minerals our bodies need to stay healthy and strong.

meanings: A swarm is a large group of insects or animals, like bees or butterflies, that move together in the same direction. It's like when a lot of kids run together to play a game on the playground!
examples: As we walked through the garden, we noticed a swarm of bees busy collecting nectar from the colorful flowers, buzzing happily as they flew from one blossom to another.
During our science class, we learned that a swarm of birds can create beautiful patterns in the sky, especially when they are trying to avoid a predator.
While camping in the woods, we saw a swarm of fireflies lighting up the night, creating a magical atmosphere that made us feel like we were in a fairy tale.
At the beach, a swarm of crabs scurried across the sand, making us laugh as they hurried to their burrows before the tide came in.
When the ice cream truck arrived at the park, a swarm of kids rushed to it, excitedly shouting their favorite flavors as they lined up for a treat.

meanings: To move or turn around a central point, like how a chair can spin to face a different direction.
examples: The office chair has a special design that allows it to swivel easily, making it simple for me to reach my desk without getting up.
During science class, we learned how a camera lens can swivel to capture images from different angles, helping photographers take amazing pictures.
My little brother loves to play with his spinning top, watching it swivel around and around until it finally wobbles and falls over.
In gym class, we practiced a dance routine where we had to swivel our hips while keeping our arms steady, which made it challenging but really fun!
The globe on my teacher's desk can swivel, allowing us to see all the different countries and oceans as we learn about world geography.

meanings: Not sure or not final; something that might change later, like a plan that isn't set in stone.
examples: My teacher gave us a tentative schedule for the field trip, which means we might visit the museum next week, but it could change depending on the weather.
During our science project, we made a tentative plan to test different types of soil, but we still needed to decide which plants we would grow in each kind.
When my friends and I made tentative plans to go to the movies this Saturday, we agreed to check in later in the week to see if everyone was still available.
The coach announced a tentative practice time for our soccer team, but he reminded us that it could change if the rain continues throughout the week.
As we read the tentative ending of the book, we started to guess what might happen next, even though the author had left some clues open for us to interpret.

meanings: Terrain is the type of land in a certain area, including its hills, valleys, and flat spaces. It helps us understand how easy or hard it is to walk, build, or play in that place.
examples: The rugged terrain of the mountain made our hike challenging, but when we reached the top, the view was absolutely breathtaking and worth the effort.
In our science class, we learned how different types of terrain, like deserts and forests, can affect the animals and plants that live there.
During our history project, we discovered that the terrain of ancient civilizations, such as rivers and mountains, played a crucial role in how they developed and thrived.
While playing our favorite video game, we had to navigate through various terrains, from sandy beaches to snowy mountains, to complete the exciting quests and challenges.
The hiking club organized a trip to explore the rugged terrain of the national park, where we would encounter beautiful landscapes and learn about the local wildlife.

meanings: A territory is a piece of land that someone or a group is in charge of or owns, like how your room is your space in your house.
examples: In history class, we learned how different countries often fought over territory to expand their land and influence, which changed the maps of the world we know today.
During our nature hike, we discovered that certain animals, like wolves, protect their territory from others to ensure they have enough food and space to live.
In the game we played at recess, each team claimed their own territory on the playground, and we had to defend it while trying to capture the other team's flag.
When my family moved into our new house, we spent the weekend exploring our backyard, which quickly became our favorite territory for playing games and having fun together.
The school decided to create a new garden in a part of the playground that wasn’t being used, turning that territory into a beautiful space for all students to enjoy.

meanings: A trace is a small mark or sign that shows someone or something was there, like footprints in the sand or a faint line on a paper.
examples: When we visited the old castle, we could see the trace of the ancient drawings on the walls, reminding us of how people lived many centuries ago.
During our science project, we learned how to trace the path of a river on a map and understand how it affects the environment around it.
As we hiked through the forest, we found a trace of animal tracks in the mud, which helped us guess which animals had passed through earlier that day.
In art class, we practiced how to trace our hands on paper to create a fun design that showed our unique fingerprints and personalities.
While cleaning my room, I noticed a faint trace of the glitter from a craft project I did last week, which reminded me of all the fun we had making decorations.

meanings: Tranquil means calm and peaceful, like a quiet lake on a sunny day where everything feels relaxed and safe.
examples: Sitting by the lake during the early morning hours, I felt a tranquil sense of peace as the sun rose and the birds began to sing.
After a long week of tests at school, I love to relax in my room with a good book, enjoying the tranquil atmosphere that helps me unwind.
When we went camping in the mountains, the tranquil sound of the river flowing nearby made it easy to fall asleep under the starry sky.
During art class, I find that painting in soft colors creates a tranquil mood that allows my creativity to flow freely and helps me focus on my work.
Listening to classical music while studying can create a tranquil environment that helps me concentrate and understand my homework better.

meanings: To transfer means to move something from one place to another, like when you take your backpack from your room to school.
examples: During the science experiment, we had to transfer the colored water from one beaker to another to see how it would mix with different substances.
When I decided to transfer my favorite books from the shelf to my bedside table, it made my reading corner feel cozy and inviting.
In soccer practice, our coach taught us how to transfer the ball quickly between players to create better scoring opportunities during the game.
When the school announced that we could transfer our lunch tables to sit with different friends, everyone was excited to make new connections.
For my birthday party, I asked my parents if we could transfer the decorations from the living room to the backyard for a fun outdoor celebration.

meanings: To transport means to move something from one place to another, like when a bus takes you to school or when you carry your backpack to your friend's house.
examples: The school bus is an important way to transport students to and from school every day, ensuring everyone arrives safely and on time for their classes.
During our science project, we learned how animals like elephants can transport heavy logs through the forest, helping to create new paths for other wildlife.
When we went to the museum on our field trip, the guide explained how ancient Egyptians used boats to transport goods along the Nile River for trade.
My dad uses his truck to transport furniture whenever someone moves into a new house, making it easier for them to settle in and feel at home.
At the science fair, my project showed how wind can transport seeds across long distances, helping plants grow in new places around the world.

meanings: Treacherous means something that is very dangerous and can trick you, like a slippery path that looks safe but is really hard to walk on.
examples: The mountain trail looked beautiful, but the guide warned us that it could be treacherous, especially if it rained and made the rocks slippery.
When we learned about the ocean's currents in science class, I was surprised to find out that they can be treacherous for boats and swimmers if they aren't careful.
During our history lesson, we discovered how explorers faced treacherous conditions while navigating uncharted waters, risking their lives for new discoveries.
As we played tag in the backyard, I realized that the muddy patches could be treacherous, making it easy to slip and fall if we weren't paying attention.
My dad explained that driving on icy roads can be treacherous, so it’s important to go slow and be extra careful to avoid accidents.

meanings: A triumph is a big win or success that makes you feel really happy and proud. It’s like when you achieve a goal or win a game after working hard.
examples: When our soccer team scored the winning goal in the last few seconds of the game, the joy we felt was a true triumph that we would remember forever.
After months of studying hard for the big science test, I felt an incredible triumph when I saw my score was the highest in the class.
Completing my first novel was a huge triumph for me, and I couldn't wait to share it with my friends and family who encouraged me along the way.
The triumph of planting a garden and watching the flowers bloom made me feel proud, knowing that I had helped create something beautiful in our backyard.
When I finally learned how to ride my bike without training wheels, my parents cheered for me, celebrating that triumph as one of the best moments of my childhood.

meanings: A tyrant is a leader who uses their power to control people unfairly and often makes decisions that hurt others instead of helping them.
examples: In history class, we learned about how a tyrant ruled over a kingdom with strict laws and made unfair decisions that hurt the people living there.
When I read the book about the ancient empire, I was shocked to discover how the tyrant treated his subjects, forcing them to work long hours without any rest or reward.
During our school debate, my classmate argued that a good leader should never act like a tyrant, because everyone deserves to have a voice and be treated fairly.
In the video game, the main character must defeat the tyrant who has taken control of the land, causing fear and sadness among the villagers who just want to live peacefully.
After watching the documentary about a famous tyrant, I felt inspired to stand up for what is right and help those who are being treated unfairly in our community.

meanings: When everyone agrees or thinks the same way about something.
examples: After discussing the new class project, the students were unanimous in choosing to create a science fair exhibit about renewable energy sources.
When the soccer team voted for their new captain, the choice was unanimous, as everyone agreed that Mia showed great leadership during practices.
During the book club meeting, the group was unanimous in deciding that the next book they would read should be a thrilling mystery.
Our family was unanimous in agreeing that we should spend our vacation at the beach this year, as we all love building sandcastles and swimming in the ocean.
The members of the student council were unanimous in their decision to organize a charity event, believing it was important to help those in need in our community.

meanings: Being one of a kind and different from everything else; there is no other person, thing, or idea exactly like it.
examples: My science project about the life cycle of a butterfly was unique because I included a video of real caterpillars transforming into beautiful butterflies, which amazed my classmates.
In art class, I created a unique painting using different textures, like sand and fabric, to make it stand out from everyone else's artwork on the wall.
During our history lesson, we learned about a unique civilization that built their homes in cliffs, which was different from any other culture we had studied before.
My grandma’s recipe for her famous chocolate chip cookies is unique because she adds a secret ingredient that makes them taste even better than regular cookies!
When we went to the zoo, I saw a unique animal called a quokka, which looked like a small kangaroo and made me laugh with its happy expression.

meanings: Not following rules or behaving badly; hard to control or manage.
examples: The unruly puppy jumped all over the living room, knocking over plants and chewing on the couch cushions while we tried to keep him calm.
During group projects, it can be challenging to work with an unruly classmate who doesn’t listen and keeps distracting everyone from getting their work done.
The teacher had to find a way to manage the unruly students in the back of the classroom who were talking loudly and not paying attention during the lesson.
My little brother is sometimes unruly when he plays video games, shouting and getting upset when he doesn’t win, which makes it hard for us to enjoy playing together.
When we went camping, the unruly wind made it difficult to set up our tents, blowing everything around and creating a big mess in our campsite.

meanings: To unveil something means to show it for the first time or to reveal it, like when a magician takes off a curtain to show their trick.
examples: During the school assembly, the principal will unveil the new playground design, which includes slides, swings, and climbing walls that everyone is excited to use.
In the science fair, my classmate is going to unveil her project on renewable energy, showing how we can use the sun and wind to power our homes.
When my favorite author visits the bookstore, she plans to unveil her latest book, which is a thrilling adventure that many of her fans have been eagerly waiting for.
At the art exhibition, the artist will unveil her new painting, which reflects her love for nature and the beauty of the changing seasons.
During our history lesson, the teacher will unveil some fascinating facts about ancient Egypt, including the secrets of the pyramids and how they were built thousands of years ago.

meanings: To leave a place where you are staying or working because you no longer need to be there. For example, when a family moves out of a house, they vacate it so someone else can move in.
examples: When the fire alarm rang at school, we had to quickly vacate the building and gather in the field to make sure everyone was safe.
After the summer camp ended, we had to vacate our cabins and say goodbye to our new friends before heading home.
The teacher asked us to vacate our seats so that she could rearrange the classroom for the exciting science fair project we were working on.
As the concert came to an end, the audience began to vacate their seats, buzzing with excitement about the amazing performances they had just witnessed.
When the old playground equipment was removed, the kids had to vacate the area while the workers set up the brand new swings and slides.

meanings: To completely defeat someone in a game or competition, making sure they cannot win.
examples: In the exciting video game, the hero must vanquish the evil sorcerer to save the enchanted kingdom and restore peace to the land.
During our science project competition, we worked hard to vanquish our rivals by creating the most impressive volcano model that erupted with colorful lava.
In the history lesson, we learned how brave knights would often vanquish their foes in battle, proving their courage and strength in the Middle Ages.
When the school soccer team played against their toughest opponents, they trained every day to vanquish them and win the championship trophy at the end of the season.
As I read my favorite book, I was inspired by the main character who had to vanquish her fears in order to embark on a thrilling adventure.

meanings: A vat is a big container that holds liquids, like water or juice, and is often used in factories or kitchens to mix or store things.
examples: In science class, we learned that a vat is used to mix different chemicals together safely, creating colorful reactions that help us understand how substances interact.
At the candy factory tour, we saw a giant vat filled with melted chocolate, and I couldn't believe how much it took to make all those delicious treats.
During the history lesson, our teacher explained how ancient people used large vats to store water and food, which was really important for their survival.
When we visited the local brewery with our parents, we watched as workers carefully poured ingredients into a massive vat to create different types of beer.
In our art project, we used a large vat to mix paint colors, which allowed us to create beautiful, unique shades for our masterpieces.

meanings: Velocity is how fast something is moving and the direction it's going. For example, if a car is going 60 miles per hour to the north, that speed and direction together make up its velocity.
examples: The velocity of a soccer ball can change quickly when a player kicks it, making it fly in different directions during the game.
In science class, we learned that the velocity of a roller coaster affects how thrilling the ride is, especially when it zooms down steep hills.
When I ride my bike down a hill, the velocity increases so fast that I can feel the wind rushing past me and it makes me giggle with excitement.
The velocity of a cheetah is incredible, as it can run up to 60 miles per hour, making it the fastest land animal in the world.
During our physics experiment, we measured the velocity of toy cars racing down a ramp, and it was exciting to see which car went the fastest!

meanings: A verdict is the decision that a jury makes after a trial, telling whether someone is guilty or innocent of a crime. It’s like when a group of friends decides who should win a game after watching how everyone played.
examples: After hours of deliberation, the jury finally reached a verdict, declaring the defendant guilty of stealing the priceless painting from the museum.
In our class debate about whether school uniforms should be mandatory, the teacher gave her verdict, deciding that we should vote on the issue to hear everyone's opinion.
When the science fair projects were judged, the verdict from the teachers praised the creativity and hard work displayed by all the students, making everyone feel proud of their efforts.
After a long soccer game, the coach announced the verdict: our team had won the championship, and we all jumped up and down with excitement.
In the end, the book club came to a verdict about the story; we all agreed that the ending was surprising and made us think about the characters' choices.

meanings: Versatile means being able to do many different things well or being useful in many ways, like a Swiss Army knife that has tools for different tasks.
examples: The Swiss Army knife is a versatile tool because it can be used for cutting, screwing, and opening bottles all in one small package.
In art class, we learned that clay is a versatile medium; you can mold it into different shapes, and then paint it any color you like.
During science class, we discovered that the versatile Amazon rainforest is home to countless plants and animals, each playing a unique role in the ecosystem.
My mom says that cooking is a versatile skill because you can create delicious meals from simple ingredients, and it’s a fun way to impress your friends.
When we play games, I love how versatile my favorite board game is, allowing us to choose different strategies and make new rules every time we play.

meanings: A veteran is a person who has a lot of experience doing a job, especially someone who has served in the military and has fought in wars.
examples: The science club invited a veteran scientist to speak about his exciting discoveries, and we learned so much about the wonders of space and the universe.
During our history lesson, we met a veteran who shared his experiences from the war, helping us understand the sacrifices made for our country’s freedom.
My dad is a veteran of the football team, and he taught me all the best strategies to win our games during practice.
In art class, we had a veteran painter visit, and he showed us how to use different techniques to create beautiful landscapes on canvas.
At the community center, a veteran chef held a cooking class, where he shared his favorite recipes and tips for making delicious meals at home.

meanings: Vicinity means the area that is close to a specific place, like the neighborhoods or streets around your school or home.
examples: The science fair will take place in our school gym, so students from the entire vicinity are excited to showcase their projects and see what everyone else has created.
During our nature walk, we spotted a family of deer in the vicinity of the creek, and we quietly watched them without disturbing their peaceful surroundings.
My parents told me that there are several interesting historical sites in the vicinity of our town, and I can’t wait to visit them with my classmates on our field trip.
While playing soccer in the park, we noticed that some kids from the vicinity had joined us, and soon we had enough players for a fun match.
The new video game store opened in the vicinity of the mall, and my friends and I are planning to check it out this weekend to see what cool games they have.

meanings: A victor is a person who has won a competition or battle. It's someone who comes out on top and achieves victory over others.
examples: After an intense soccer match, the team celebrated their triumph as the victor, knowing all their hard work in practice had paid off.
In the school spelling bee, Mia was named the victor after correctly spelling the last challenging word, and her classmates cheered loudly in support.
The science fair was full of impressive projects, but it was Jake's innovative robot that made him the victor of the competition, winning him a special trophy.
During the annual chess tournament, Alex emerged as the victor after a tense final game, impressing everyone with his strategic moves and quick thinking.
In the history quiz, Sarah became the victor by answering all the questions correctly, and she was thrilled to share her prize with her teammates.

meanings: To violate means to break a rule or law, like when someone doesn't follow the safety rules at school or at home.
examples: If students decide to cheat on a test, they violate the trust that their teachers and classmates have in them to be honest and fair.
When you ignore the rules of a game, you violate the spirit of competition and make it less enjoyable for everyone involved.
Throwing trash on the ground during a nature hike can violate the park's rules and harm the environment we all want to protect.
If you talk during a presentation, you might violate the classroom's respect policy, which is important for everyone to hear the speaker clearly.
When someone uses their phone during class instead of focusing on the lesson, they violate school rules that help students learn better.

meanings: Vital means something that is very important and needed for life or to succeed at something. For example, food and water are vital for our bodies to stay healthy.
examples: Staying hydrated is vital for athletes because drinking enough water helps them perform their best during games and practice.
In science class, we learned that trees are vital to our environment because they provide oxygen and homes for many animals.
When studying for a big test, it's vital to get a good night's sleep so your brain can remember all the information you learned.
During a team project, effective communication is vital, as it helps everyone understand their roles and work together successfully.
In our community, volunteering at the local shelter is vital because it helps support families in need and makes a positive impact on everyone's lives.

meanings: To wend means to move or travel in a certain direction, often taking your time or going a roundabout way. It’s like when you walk through a park, enjoying the scenery instead of rushing straight to the exit.
examples: As we wend our way through the forest, the towering trees and chirping birds make our hike feel like an adventure from a storybook.
During our field trip to the museum, we wended through the exhibits, taking our time to learn about dinosaurs and ancient civilizations.
After finishing my homework, I decided to wend my way to the park, enjoying the fresh air and sunshine along the path.
As the sun began to set, we wended our way home from the beach, collecting seashells and laughing about our fun day.
When my friends and I play video games, we often wend through different levels, trying to find hidden treasures and secrets along the way.

meanings: Woe means a feeling of deep sadness or trouble. It’s like when something really bad happens, and you feel very upset or unhappy about it.
examples: When the basketball team lost the championship game, the players felt a deep sense of woe, knowing all their hard work had not led to the victory they had hoped for.
As I watched my favorite video game character get defeated by the final boss, I couldn't help but feel a wave of woe wash over me because I wanted them to win.
After my best friend moved away, I experienced a lot of woe, realizing that I would miss our daily adventures and all the fun we had together.
While reading a book about a brave knight, I felt the character's woe when he lost his beloved horse, making me understand how much he cared.
The news report about the forest fire caused me great woe, as I thought about all the animals that lost their homes and the beautiful trees that were destroyed.
